name: technical_debt_management_2025
context: A psychometric inventory designed for software engineers working in the fast-paced development environments of 2025. This survey investigates how developers navigate the perpetual tension between delivering new features rapidly ('shipping') and maintaining long-term code health. It assesses individual philosophies on code quality, willingness to tolerate 'spaghetti code' for short-term gains, and preferences regarding when (or if) to pay down accumulated technical debt.

questions.preprompt: Considering {player_name}'s daily workflow and priorities as a developer, how strongly does {player_name} agree with this statement?
questions.statement: Getting a feature into the hands of users is more important than ensuring the underlying code is elegant.

questions.preprompt: Reflecting on how {player_name} handles project deadlines, to what extent does {player_name} agree?
questions.statement: It is better to delay a release significantly than to ship code that feels 'hacky' or unstable.

questions.preprompt: When thinking about trade-offs in development, what is {player_name}'s stance on the following?
questions.statement: {player_name} is comfortable merging 'quick and dirty' solutions if it means meeting a critical sprint goal.

questions.preprompt: Thinking about {player_name}'s approach to code reviews and quality standards, how does {player_name} feel about this?
questions.statement: {player_name} feels physical discomfort when asked to compromise on code structure or best practices.

questions.preprompt: Regarding {player_name}'s willingness to refactor versus build new things, to what extent does {player_name} agree?
questions.statement: Spending time refactoring old code feels like a waste of time compared to building new features.

questions.preprompt: Considering the long-term maintainability of the codebase, how does {player_name} view this statement?
questions.statement: {player_name} believes that technical debt should be paid down immediately, even if it halts all new feature development.

questions.preprompt: When evaluating a pull request or their own work, how strongly does {player_name} agree?
questions.statement: Good enough is better than perfect.
